div1.head: John Gault and J.C. Ayer: Encased Postage Stamp Maker and His Largest Client

p.hi: Coinage of the Americas Conference at the American Numismatic Society, New York City

div1.p: © The American Numismatic Society, 1995

This paper discusses the two men most responsible for the Encased Postage Stamps manufactured as a substitute for small change during the U.S. Civil War: John Gault, their inventor and manufacturer, and J.C. Ayer, Gault's largest client.1

div2.p: Throughout history, times of war have been times of great upheaval and change. Hostilities greatly alter local and national economies. The U.S. Civil War brought about vast changes in the circulating money of the nation. Citizens on both sides of the conflict began hoarding gold and silver, and before long there was a severe shortage of coins in circulation. Commerce began to suffer, and soon the population resorted to all manner of substitutes for small change.

Some grocers took to filling packets with 25 cents worth of flour, to be given in change in place of quarters. Other merchants and individuals began printing their own paper money in small denominations to be used as change. These promissory "scrip" notes could be redeemed only by their issuers. Shoppers found themselves with pocketfuls of IOU's at the end of the day, each good only at the place of issue.

Postage stamps were also pressed into service. While these had a universal value, they also had a severe drawback: once soiled by circulation, they would be worthless as postage. The adhesive backing posed further problems. Humidity and moisture from people's hands caused the stamps to stick to whatever surface they came in contact with.

One solution was to place stamps inside protective envelopes, with the value written on the outside of the envelope. Printers and merchants eased the burden by producing small envelopes with values printed on the outside. While the envelopes protected the stamps, they did not protect recipients from miscreants who would place stamp-size squares of paper in the envelopes and pass them at full value.

An entrepreneur from Boston named John Gault devised a solution to this dilemma: the encased postage stamp. Gault's invention provided a way to protect stamps while still allowing them to be seen. The stamps were laid on a brass disk with a small piece of cardboard backing between. Atop the stamp was placed a disk of clear mica. Finally, a brass frame was bent around the sandwich, locking
the components together. About the size of a quarter, Gault's encasement allowed stamps to circulate without fear of damage or fraud.

Gault received a patent for his invention on August 12, 1862, and contracted their production to the Scovill Manufacturing Company. Since encased stamps would circulate at the face value of the stamp, Gault needed a way to cover the cost of their manufacture (not to mention his profit margin). His solution to this problem was as American as apple pie: he sold advertising on the back of the stamp case!

Merchants would pay Gault a premium to produce encased postage stamps with their message on the back. Eventually 31 merchants (including Gault himself) would advertise 34 different products on his encasements. Each piece carried its message from person to person as it changed hands in the marketplace. Gault's advertisers included some of the biggest merchandisers of the day. Amazingly, some of these businesses are still in operation today: the Lord & Taylor department store (New York City), Shillito's department store (Cincinnati), and Bailey, Banks & Biddle jewelers.

Eight denominations of stamps were used in Gault's encasements: 1¢, 3¢, 5¢, 10¢, 12¢, 24¢, 30¢, and 90¢. The four smallest denominations corresponded to circulating coins and are the most common. The larger odd-value denominations were used only for postage and would have been more difficult to use in circulation. The 24¢, 30¢, and 90¢ encasements are very rare.

John Gault was born in Baltimore in 1831 to Irish immigrants John Gault, Sr. and Mary Ann Magee (born 1798). He had two brothers and one sister: older brother Henry (born 1827), younger brother Samuel (born 1839) and sister Ann. Around 1840 the family moved to Boston. The senior Gault passed away in 1847. The discovery of gold in 1849 enticed young John to California in search of his fortune. He embarked on a ship sailing around the Horn of Africa. He visited several South American countries along the six month voyage. After five years in California he returned to Boston, where he worked in a machine shop and lived with his mother and 16-year-old brother Samuel.

John Gault's skill as a machinist, combined with his entrepenurial zeal, led him to patent several inventions, including a lock stitch device for sewing machines, an illuminated coal hole cover, and an eraser sharpener. As the nation headed toward the Civil War, he turned his attention to armaments, patenting three kinds of artillery
shells. Fig. 1 shows a patent drawing for a Projectile, awarded to Gault on July 2, 1862.

Later that same month, on July 24, Gault applied for the patent for which he is known in numismatic and philatelic circles today—a "Design for Postage Stamp Case" (fig. 2). The patent drawing is still on file at the National Archives in Washington. The drawing shows seven figures of varying sizes. The accompanying documentation has been lost over the years. The original patent model somehow escaped that fate. It was recently sold at auction by Bowers and Merena. The patent model features a 10 cent Washington stamp. The reverse shows the words "John Gault Business Card" in script lettering. Attached is a file card inscribed with the name and date of the patent (fig. 3).

John Gault was 31 years old when his Encased Postage patent was granted on August 12th, 1862. Four days later, on August 16th, his younger brother Samuel, now 23 and employed as a bookkeeper, enlisted with the 38th Regiment of the Massachusetts Volunteers. Samuel was commissioned as a captain on December 4th, 1862. In that same year their 64 year-old mother was diagnosed with insanity.

With his mother under medical care and his younger brother off fighting the war, Gault began manufacturing his new product. Among the first encased postage stamps produced were those bearing the name of the inventor. These were undoubtably created by Gault to double as advertising pieces for his own business and samples for potential advertising clients. These pieces were inscribed simply "Pat Aug 12, 1862" (top) and "J. Gault" (bottom). These encasements were produced in all eight standard denominations:

lg.l: One cent, blue, portrait of Franklin
Three cent, rose, portrait of Washington
Five cent, red-brown, portrait of Jefferson
Ten cent, green, portrait of Washington (fig. 4)
Twelve cent, black, portrait of Washington
Twenty-four cent, red-lilac, portrait of Washington
Thirty Cent, orange, portrait of Franklin
Ninety cent, blue, portrait of Washington

div2.p: Since Gault had lived in Boston, it seems natural that many of the issuers of encased postage stamps were based in Massachusetts. The largest of these was J. C. Ayer & Co. of Lowell, MA. Ayer manufactured medicines (fig. 5). His products were used around the world. Three different Ayer's messages graced Gault's encased postage stamps: Ayer's Cathartic Pills, Ayer's Sarsaparilla, and Take Ayer's Pills. Ayer's pieces are the most common of all encased postage stamps. A total of six New England merchants issued Gault's encasements.

James Cook Ayer was born in Ledyard, Connecticut on May 5, 1818. His parents were Persis Cook Ayer (born May 8, 1796) and Frederick Ayer (born August 17, 1792). His younger brother Frederick Ayer, Jr. was born on December 8, 1822. There were two sisters, Fanny and Laurisa.

When the senior Ayer died in 1825, Persis moved the family to the nearby town of Preston, where her father operated a flannel mill. Young J.C. Ayer had his first mechanical training in the mill. He later moved to Lowell, MA to live with his uncle James Cook. Cook had served as a corporal in the War of 1812; he was a manufacturer and was one of the early mayors of Lowell. As brother Frederick wrote many years later: Uncle James Cook...became acquainted with my brother, took a fancy to him, took him with him to
Lowell, and sent him to Westford Academy to complete his education. After graduation, James took a clerkship with Mr. Robbins in his drugstore [in the summer of 1838], and boarded with Uncle James; and as Uncle James had no children, I have always understood that my brother supplied that place to some extent, making himself both useful and entertaining, for both of which qualities he had a rare gift. During his leisure hours in the store he applied himself to the study of the compounding of medicine, and qualified as a physician. Mr. Robbins' place, being a leading drug store in the city, was much visited by the physicians which gave James a rare opportunity of becoming familiar with them, and many of them became interested in him to the extent of taking him with them if they had unusual cases or operations. After about two years with Mr. Robbins James purchased the store and ran it under his own name.

J. C. Ayer purchased the drug store in April 1841. He was just 23 years old. The purchase Price was $2,486.61, which he borrowed from his uncle and repaid in three years. As reported by Frederick: The business suggested to James the need of some standard remedy which physicians could order for coughs and colds. This suggestion was warmly approved by the doctors; and the result, Cherry Pectoral, was generally ordered by them for those complaints. Without other notice its fame grew until the demand induced him to put it up for the general market. From this time the business of supplying the market absorbed him so much that he took...a partner to run the drug store.

On November 14, 1850, 32 year-old J. C. Ayer married Josephine Mellen Southwick. The couple purchased a large historic stone tavern on Pawtucket Street as their residence. They had three children: Frederick Fanning, Henry Southwick, and Lesley Josephine. As a relative wrote in an 1859 letter: Mrs. Ayer is a jolly, easy woman,...very girlish in her ways and quite witty. They live in an immense stone house. It is furnished quite nicely and handsomely, but there is little display....

In 1855 Ayer sent for his brother Frederick, who was managing a general store in Syracuse, NY, and invited him to become his business partner. Frederick sold his interest in the general store and returned to Lowell where he became a one-third partner in J.C. Ayer
& Co. Frederick lived with his brother's family until his own marriage in December, 1858. As Frederick wrote in his Reminiscenes: When I went into the business with my brother the only medicine he had perfected and put upon the market was Cherry Pectoral...My brother was at that time at work on a pill for general use, which was soon after put on the market as Ayer's Cathartic Pills. Subsequently, through much labor investigation, experimentation, and study, the Sarsaparilla and Hair Vigor were also put on the market, and all of the medicines soon became very popular.

Extensive advertising was a key element in the success of J.C. Ayer & Company. The products were promoted heavily through newspaper advertisements and giveaway flyers and pamphlets. By 1871 Ayer's products were advertised in 2,000 newspapers. The company gave away millions of Ayer's Almanacs each year (fig. 6). These Alamancs were filled with advertisements and testimonials for Ayer products. The company eventually purchased its own printing plant.

One interesting international incident related to the Ayer company involves a man befriended by the Ayer sales agent in Brazil. The man was Jose Carlos Rodriguez, the Assistant Secretary of State of Brazil. Rodriguez planned a coup and tricked the Secretary of State into leaving Rio de Janeiro. But the Secretary returned early and the coup failed. Rodriguez fled to the mountains where he was harbored by the Ayers agent. Later, Rodriguez sneaked out of the country in a packing crate addressed to the J.C. Ayer Company in Lowell, MA. He was given employment translating Ayer printed matter into Portuguese, Spanish, Italian, and French. He later published his own Portuguese-language newspaper which was shipped to Brazil and caused quite an annoyance to the Emperor. [J. C. Ayer] was a most indefatigable worker...For many years he wrote the Ayer's American Almanack, which was issued in fourteen languages, with calendars adapted to the longitude of the different countries for which it was issued. He also wrote the newspaper and postal advertising matter and did much of the most important correspondence of the office. He was a reader of authors like Darwin and Huxley, and a student of the sciences and history, with an intense interest in every new development.

Ayer became interested in mining, and in 1865 he was awarded
patents for ore-reducing processes. He financed the Lake Superior Ship Canal & Railroad & Iron Company. He acquired timber lands in Florida and built saw mills nearby. He made two journeys to Europe. He died on July 3, 1878 at the age of 60. His death was said to be caused by many years of overwork and exhaustion. He was buried in Lowell Cemetery, where his grave is marked by a massive lion. His brother Frederick managed the business until his retirement in 1893.

Gault moved to New York City City and teamed up with partner Joseph Kirkpatrick. Directory listings indicate Kirkpatrick had been established at No. 1 Park Place (across from City Hall park) since at least 1860. The team of Kirkpatrick & Gault issued an encasement bearing a more extensive message than Gault's spare design:
Applications for advertising on this currency to be addressed to Kirkpatrick & Gault, No. 1 Park Place, N . Y. (fig. 7).

There were nine issuers of Encased Postage in New York City City: Aerated Bread Company, Dougan the Hatter, Drake's Plantation Bitters, Irving House, Lord & Taylor, Mendum's Family Wine Emporium, North America Life Insurance Company, S. Steinfeld, and White the Hatter. Three more were in nearby Philadelphia: J. Bailey & Co., G.G. Evans, and N & G Taylor Co. The New England, New York City, and Philadelphia issuers account for 22 of the 34 different types of encasements, and by most measures, over 85% of the total number of individual pieces.

Gault advertised his product in several newspapers. One such ad appeared in the November 6, 1862 New York City Herald: THE NEW METALLIC CURRENCY—APPLICATIONS for stamping business cards, on the new metallic currency to be made to J. GAULT, patentee, No 1 Park Place, New York City.

Gault undoubtably lured several of his clients in this time period. But with the supply of stamps running low, and the new Postal and Fractional currency notes beginning to alleviate the coin shortage, his days as a manufacturer of Encased Postage Stamps were numbered. The year 1863 also brought bad news from the battlefront: on the 13th of April, Gault's brother Samuel was killed at the battle of Teche, Louisiana.

The metallic cent-sized pieces now known as Civil War Tokens were also eating into Gault's business; so much so, apparently, that Gault decided to devote some of his business to selling them. On August 29, 1863 the following ad appeared in Harper's Weekly: PENNY TOKENS of COPPER... The best quality, and in any quantity, furnished at $8 per thousand by JOHN GAULT, No. 1 Park Place, two doors from Broadway, New York City. All orders by mail or express promptly forwarded.

With Presidential elections approaching in 1864, the entrepreneurial Gault wrote a letter to incumbent Abraham Lincoln on June 18th. Still at No. 1 Park Place, Gault wrote: Sir: I intend circulating three or four million medals in metallic cases containing likenesses of Yourself & Andrew Johnson for President and Vice President and want to get a perfect Photograph to copy from, or the one, that you would prefer to have circulated. I shall get them up in the neatest manner. If you would please send me a Likeness I shall be happy to use it to copy from.

Three weeks later, on July 9, 1864, Gault published the following ad in Harper's Weekly. PHOTOGRAPHIC MEDALLION, or CAMPAIGN MEDALS, with accurate likenesses of candidates on metal, and enclosed in neat metallic cases, sent my mail, 15 cents each, or $1.50 per dozen. Liberal discounts to the trade. Manufactured and sold wholesale by JOHN GAULT, No. 1 Park Place. New York City.
These ferrotype campaign buttons were manufactured in a similar manner to Gault's postage stamp encasements. All bear his patent date of August 12, 1862 (fig. 8).

New York City directory listings for Gault are incomplete after the war. The 1864-65 directory lists his occupation enigmatically as "Oil".
On September 3, 1868, Gault's mother passed away in a Boston lunatic asylum. That same year he appears in the directory at 71 Broadway operating a liquor business.

About 1870 the 39 year-old Gault married the 42 year-old Pamela Patten Pryor (born April 15, 1828), a native of East Windsor, Connecticut. The couple had no children. John Gault apparently settled into the liquor business for the rest of his career. He continued the business at the 71 Broadway address until 1893, when he was 62. The Gaults travelled extensively, spending many of their winters in Florida and Virginia. From 1898 they lived at the Murray Hill Hotel, 1038 Fifth Avenue.
Following a six-month illness, Gault died on March 19, 1900, at the age of 70 (fig. 9). The cause of death was chronic nephritis, or Bright's Disease.

There are many similarities in the lives of the two men who were primarily responsible for the issue of Encased Postage Stamps during the U.S. Civil War. John Gault and James Cook Ayer both lost their fathers before reaching adulthood. They were both tinkerers and inventors who worked hard to earn their fortunes at an early age, and both married late in life. They each foresaw a need in the marketplace, and created and sold a product to fill that need, while making extensive use of advertising.

Encased Postage Stamps were just one small aspect of their respective careers. For Ayer, they were just one more piece of advertising material he used to promote his vast business enterpise. For Gault,
they were just one invention and business venture among many. For today's collectors, they are one colorful component of the history of America's coinage.

note.p:
This paper relies heavily on the research efforts of Robert Kincaid, who worked tirelessly to track down original census data, death records, obituaries, and other information at great personal expense. He and Fred L. Reed III directed my efforts in the New York City Public Library, The New-York Historical Society, and the Princeton University Library. This project was my introduction to the world of numismatic research, and I am grateful to these two gentlemen for the opportunity to help and learn. I would also like to thank the American Numismatic Society for their kind invitation to participate in COAC 1994. Quotations ascribed to Frederick Ayer are from his The Reminiscences of Frederick Ayer (Boston, 1923)
Additional information was compiled from Harper's Weekly, November 6, 1862; August 29, 1863; July 9, 1864; and The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Massachusetts Soldiers, Sailors and Marines in the Civil War Period, vol. 4 (Norwood, MA, 1933). The standard reference for encased postage stamps is currently Michael J.Hodder and David Q. Bowers, The Standard Catalogue of Encased Postage Stamps (Wolfeboro, NH, 1989). It will soon be supplanted by Reed's forthcoming book, Civil War Encased Stamps, The Issuers and Their Times.
For permission to reproduce the illustrations included herein, the author is grateful to Fred L. Reed III (figs. 1,4); Robert Kincaid (figs. 6-7); and Q. David Bowers (figs. 8-9). The remaining illustrations (figs. 2-3, 5), are from the author's collection.

div1.head: Struck Copies of Early American Tokens

p.hi: Coinage of the Americas Conference at the American Numismatic Society, New York City

div1.p: © The American Numismatic Society, 1995

Many years ago someone offered two 1785 Confederatio coppers, one with the stars in a small circle (fig. 1), and the other with the stars in a large circle (fig. 2). The coins were high grade and the Price was $10,000 each. According to the "Red Book" the Price was very reasonable.1

In the back of my mind was a pamphlet on Struck Copies of Early American Coins.2 The Confederatio cents were described on page 8. The author, Richard D. Kenney, said that in 1863, John A. Bolen of Springfield, MA, struck two of each type in silver and 40 in copper, then destroyed the dies. The dies were nicely made, with only slight differences from the genuine coins. To make certain that his copies would not be taken for the genuine examples, Bolen placed a dot in the Y of TYRANNIS as a secret mark. This mark was present on both pieces offered to me (fig. 3).

I showed the book to the owner of the two pieces and he lowered the Price slightly—to $5.00 each—which seemed reasonable. There were a few other oddities in my collection, and some of them were mentioned in the book. So I started to collect them—not too seriously—just when they came along.

The article by Kenney was the first in a new series of Wayte Raymond's The Coin Collector's Journal (Vol. 19, No. 1), issued in 1952. It sold for $1.00 or was part of the yearly subscription at $3.00 per year. The booklet covers copies struck from dies, but Kenney deliberately omitted some copies. The copies of C. Wyllys Betts and Tom Elder are "too numerous to mention here and are deserving of separate studies." One of the coins struck by Betts was the New Haven "Restrike" of the Fugio cent, which contained narrow rings compared to the wide rings on the original coins.

Bolen also had dies made and struck 65 Bar Cents, 40 Higley Coppers, 40 Carolina Tokens, 40 New York City Liber Natus Eagles, and 40 Clinton Cents. A few silver pieces and brass examples were struck from most dies, and many mules were made by mixing the dies. Some of the dies were sold to others, who made additional copies.

Alfred S. Robinson, a coin dealer (also banker, broker, etc.) from Hartford, CT, struck many copies, including the Non Vi Virtute Vici, Rosa Americana, Brasher Doubloon, New England Token, and several other tokens and medals. One piece, the Washington Cent of 1789, is thought to be a complete fabrication, as no original is known.

William Idler, a Philadelphia coin dealer, issued copies of the Washington Half Dollar and Baltimore Penny. These were certainly not meant to deceive, because he placed his advertisement on them (fig. 4).

Dr. Frank S. Edwards was a serious coin collector in New York City. He had dies made for the 1796 Half Cent, with pole. When he died in 1865, the dies and all but 12 pieces were destroyed. He also struck copies of the IMMUNE COLUMBIA / NOVA CONSTELLATIO pieces,
shown by Crosby in his book,3 but Kenney was not able to find one.

Prof. Montroville W. Dickeson, author of the American Numismatical Manual (Philadelphia, 1859), in 1859 struck copies of the Bermuda "Hogge" Tokens and later made copies of the U.S. Continental Dollar. The Dollar was struck for the 1876 Centennial celebration. Fifty specimens were struck in silver. The dies were much better than the originals, and there is little chance of confusing the two. The dies were acquired by Thomas L. Elder, a famous New York City dealer, and later by Robert Bashlow, who struck thousands of copies. Bashlow also bought the dies for the Confederate Cent, and struck thousands of them in many different metals, fibre, etc. The dies had been used by Hazeltine to make 74 restrikes in 1874, then damaged by striking them with an axe. Bashlow's restrikes show all of the damage. The dies for the Continental Dollar were not damaged, however; it may not be possible to differentiate betweeen Dickeson's and Bashlow's restrikes.

The Birmingham (England) firm of Kettle & Sons made coppergilt or brass imitations of 1803 U.S. Quarter Eagles and Half Eagles for gaming counters (fig. 5). They were not made to deceive, because the name KETTLE was placed at the right of the date (fig. 6). On some coins this name has been removed and may be confusing (see center coin in fig. 5).

Horace M. Grant, a Providence, RI, dealer, had copies of the 1779 Rhode Island Token made in 1936 (fig. 7). He had his initials H.M.G. placed on the crest of the wave below Howe's battleship (fig. 8).

One of the most copied of early coins is the Pine Tree Shilling. These were copied by many firms, including Whitehead and Hoag, the Roberts Company, International Sterling Company (fig. 9), and by Thomas Elder.
Emerson produced copies of the 1788 Massachusetts Cent and Half Cent (fig. 10). They were nicely done, and Emerson had a tiny "E" placed over the star in front of the head of the Indian (fig. 11).

One of the copies made by C. Wyllys Betts was the New Haven "Restrike" of the Fugio Cent. This was made from dies copied from the original in 1860. The interlocking rings are much narrower in cross section than are the originals.

My favorites are the copies made by Thomas Wyatt of the New England Shilling and Sixpence (fig. 12). Unable to obtain actual coins for the engraver to copy, Wyatt furnished a copy of Felt's 1839 book on Massachusetts currency.4 which in turn was copied from Folkes's English Coinage, published in 1763.5 Felt carried over the horizontal lines used by Folkes to add shading to the illustrations. In turn, Wyatt's engraver faithfully copied each line, and they show very prominently on the coins struck from his dies (fig. 13)! Wyatt issued eight copies in all, including the Oak Tree Shilling and Twopence, the Pine Tree Sixpence, Threepence, and Penny and the Good Samaritan Shilling (itself a fabricaton).6

With the differences between the original coins and these copies, it is evident that the copies were struck to furnish examples of the rare coins for collectors. This is also shown by the personal marks added by the makers. These marks made it easy to differentiate between the originals and the copies. Of course, the marks could be removed, as was the "KETTLE" on one coin, but an honest effort had been made.

note.p: R.S. Yeoman, Guide Book of United States Coins, 47th rev. edition, Kenneth Bressett, ed. (Iola, WI, 1994), p. 37.
Richard D. Kenney, "Struck Copies of early American Coins," The Coin Collector's Journal, Jan.-Feb. 1952, pp. 1-16.
Sylvester S.Crosby, The Early Coins of America (Boston, 1875), p. 316.
Joseph B. Felt, An Historical Account of the Massachusetts Currency (Boston, 1839), plate opposite p. 248.
Martin Folkes, Tables of English Silver and Gold Coins (London, 1763), pl. 30 [silver], nos. 4-5.
Eric P. Newman, The Secret of the Good Samaritan Shilling, ANSNNM 142 (New York City, 1959).

div1.head: An Overview of United States Tokens, 1700-1900

p.hi: Coinage of the Americas Conference at the American Numismatic Society, New York City

div1.p: © The American Numismatic Society, 1995

The American Numismatic Society is to be commended for staging this 1994 conference on "The Token: America's Other Money," and for its choice of Richard Doty of the Smithsonian Institution as conference chairman. The timing of the conference was exquisite since tokens are rapidly evolving into one of the most active and most interesting of all numismatic disciplines, and just two months ago there was released the Standard Catalog of United States Tokens 1700-1900, a project toward which my personal efforts have been aimed for well over 30 years.1 This paper examines the role of the token during the past two centuries.

div2.p: In general, a token is a metallic substitute for government coinage, or else a form of coin-like advertising. There are so many exceptions and supplements to this basic rule that intriguing debate could rage for hours over the semantics.

Within obvious limitations, a token is whatever we choose to describe by this term, remembering that the line between token and medal is thin and tenuous. Sometimes even the line between token and coin is unclear.

A token does not have to be made of metal to deserve that term. Cardboard chits for value are usually considered tokens rather than paper money, for example, and technology in the nineteenth century introduced celluloid, vulcanite and other substances to the token world, joining leather, mother-of-pearl and other non-metallic exceptions.

Various groups of purists, from time to time, try to narrow the meaning of the word token. Many say a token must be "worth" something to be truly a token. For example, it must be "good for" 5 cents, one shave, one ride, one bushel or one task. They overlook America's great tradition of store cards. We have no objection to such redefinition efforts because we know they are well-intended—but doomed.

English is a living language. Numismatists can influence it, but only time and wide public acceptance can constrict it. This author has never subscribed to any ideological or semantic effort in his token writings, always preferring "useful" to "pure." One quality a token must have, however, is set in concrete: a token must not have been issued by a government for any clear legal tender purpose.

head.hi: The Beginnings of Tokens in America

div2.p:
It is easy to flatter ourselves that the English colonies in America
were the first to introduce tokens, in the early eighteenth century. But the facts are quite different.

Spanish America's civilization preceded our own in this activity by up to 150 years. Mexican tlacos and pilones may have appeared as early as 1550, and narrative accounts in Chile and Peru mention private mitads in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. Mexico was inundated with private tlacos and pilones by 1753. My 1992 catalog, Latin American Tokens 1700-1920 sets forth source data on this subject.2

What is now the United States did precede Canada in token issuance, for whatever nationalistic comfort that may afford us. Our very first token appears to have been the Rigault & Dawson brass 12-pence of Gloucester County, Virgina, bearing dates 1714 and 1715. The exact purpose for which the so-called "Gloucester shilling" was issued is not known, but it may have been a tobacco warehouse tally.
The first token to achieve fairly good acceptance was the 1737 copper threepence of Samuel Higley of Granby, Connecticut.

New York City City's 1789-dated Mott halfpenny token has long been considered America's first true trade token, but research in recent years has clouded even further its murky provenance. It may well have been issued after 1807 (fig. 1).

Toward the end of the eighteenth century, America was infected with the British Conder token craze, which may account for the 1794/95 cents of Talbot, Allum & Lee of New York City, as well as the spate of George Washington coppers dated as early as 1783 (though believed issued over the period 1791 to 1820).

Many collectors consider these eighteenth century issues to be part of America's colonial coin story. The 1766-dated coppers of The Friends of Liberty and Trade struck by James Smither of Philadelphia also dance along that fine line between coin, token and medal.

The year 1823 is a safe one to use as the beginning date for the wider use of trade tokens in America. English immigrant Richard Trested opened his token-making business in New York City City that year, and the Kettle firm in Birmingham, England, began exporting
American trade tokens such as those of Tredwell Kissam and C. & I.D. Wolfe.

Most early trade tokens were intended to—and did—serve duty as a cent. In some instances higher denomination coins were imitated, especially German silver "bits" (12 1/2 cents), but in the main the large copper cent of the U.S. Mint from 1793 on was the object of imitation.

The Hard Times era of Jacksonian democracy led in 1833 to a dramatic expansion in token making. It has been estimated that in 1837 as much as one-third of all copper cents in circulation were in fact tokens, not Mint-struck cents.

Token motifs and sizes—and metallic content—started changing dramatically in the 1848-51 period. Replacing the copper "cents" and German silver dime (or bit) imitations, several variations now came into vogue.

Brass replaced copper as the dominant token metal, and imitations of United States $10 and $5 gold coins started to appear, displaying the Coronet Liberty Head or Eagle Displayed along with a commercial message. Often they were issued with reeded edges and were gilded before striking to further enhance the similarity.

Counterstamped coins had been used sparingly as tokens as early as 1800 and were still infrequent through the end of the Hard Times period in 1844, but their usage widened from 1845 on. A great many of these are awaiting attribution, but remarkable strides have been made in the past 15 years, especially since we Numismatists are concentrating on the metalsmith trades for name matches. By "metalsmith" I mean every trade from silversmith and gunsmith to brazier, pewterer, cutler and clockmaker.

German silver, cupronickel, white metal and various bronzes were pressed into token use after 1845, along with silver and lead. Even gold strikes are known, most probably created as vanity pieces for affluent collectors of the day.

In 1857 the United States Mint changed the large copper cent to a small cupronickel piece, and banned further legal tender status for foreign coins. Token sizes quickly followed the 29mm to 19mm cent reduction, and vast quantities of worn-out Spanish silver became available for more counterstamping activity.

The decade of the 1850s, though, saw less monetary usage for tokens, and store cards reigned supreme. At least, those pieces larger than 19mm were seldom offered as money substitutes. But in 1858 a new phenomenon occurred: 19mm copper cent-sized "store cards" appeared in Chicago and elsewhere which not only imitated the Flying Eagle Cent reverse but passed current as private cents. This latter event foreshadowed the Civil War token.

Only in two periods of American history have the need for a private token coinage been absolute, because the reigning authority proved unable to provide a circulating medium of small change sufficient to the needs of commerce.

These two periods were the Colonial/Early Republican era, and the period of the War Between the States. In the first instance the colonial masters in Great Britain failed their subjects in America, but in the second instance people began hoarding hard currency, even one-cent pieces, in 1862. Within a year there was no one willing to pay out coin of the realm even though the Mint remained in operation.

All sorts of paper substitutes for small change appeared, from paper scrip and cardboard chits to postage stamps, both encased and loose. The needs of commerce demanded something more durable, and private small cents of copper, brass, etc., appeared in huge numbers. Some 25 million Civil War tokens must have been in circulation in late 1863, whereas there had been perhaps 10 million Hard Times tokens in public hands in 1837.

More than 11,000 varieties of Civil War tokens are cataloged, making this by far the largest period of token issuance in America until that time. A federal law in 1864 cut off most further token issuance, as the U.S. realized its sovereign coinage right was actually being imperiled by this unbridled expansion of unbacked money supply.
The 1864 law supposedly banned the use of tokens as money, but such laws worked no better in America in the nineteenth century industrializing period than they did anywhere else in the world.

Imitation cents and counterstamped coins kept appearing well into the 70s, and that decade also saw vulcanite store cards, "shell cards" (imitations of silver dollars or double eagles made of embossed metal faces bonded to paper backs), and something quite new, the "trade token." The trade token was a utilitarian emission "good for" a drink, a bath, 5 cents, 12 1/2 cents, a cord (of Wood), a meal or even a visit to a bordello. Billiard table and saloon fixture manufacturers were quick to supply their customers with tokens, and the number and variety of trade tokens which appeared in the last 30 years of the nineteenth century is quite large. This area of attribution is now being researched by scholars in every state of the Union, with a great number of varieties already documented. In most cases, individual trade token issues appear to have been small—perhaps
100 to 1,000 pieces—but it requires little imagination to realize that with one to two million possible issuers, the number of pieces in public hands by 1890 must have been staggering.
Store cards of beauty continued to be issued after the Civil War, especially connected with the 1876 Centennial Fair in Philadelphia and the 1893 Columbian Exposition in Chicago.
The commercial introduction of aluminum to token manufacture began about 1891, and by the turn of the century the cheap, beautiful and durable metal expanded token usage even further.

It has been said that in early America (before 1840), tokens were sort of a status symbol for successful merchants. Sixty years later every saloonkeeper, general store proprietor, dry goods dealer, druggist and corner grocer who wanted tokens could have them. They had become truly the money of the people—or maybe they always were!

head.hi: The State of Token Research in America

div2.p: This subject might well be treated in depth in another paper, but a few words in closing this paper seem in order. I can state with conviction that the status of token research in America has never been healthier! One of my colleagues stated in a review recently that all token catalogers are "highly idiosyncratic...to one degree or another." Another opined that serendipity was a useful, even necessary, characteristic for catalogers of tokens.

Perhaps both are right, but both miss the point. Cataloging tokens is very, very hard work. Fortunately for our beloved hobby, we are blessed in 1994 with the largest number of devoted researches we've ever had. Organizations that deserve special mention in this regard include: Token and Medal Societyr, Active Token Collectors Organization, Civil War Token Society, Maryland Token and Medal Society, American Vecturist Association, and California Exonumist Society.

note.p: Russell Rulau, Standard Catalog of United States Tokens, 1700-1900 (Iola, WI, 1994). Copies of the new 824-page illustrated, priced catalogue have been donated to the excellent ANS library, and it is my hope that users will have as much enjoyment in its perusal as my contributors and I had in writing it.
Russell Rulau, Latin American Tokens, 1700-1920 (Iola, WI, 1992).
